W. 1.15th March, 1957.CYPRUSDRAFT statement the Representative of Her Majesty's Government on the north atlantic Council has received a communication from the Secretary-General, Lord Ismay, offering his good offices for conciliation on the cyprus question, in accordance with the resolution on the peaceful settlement of disputes which was adopted by the North Atlantic Councillast December. The representative of Her Majesty's Government hasbeen instructed to inform Lord Ismay in reply that Her Majesty's Govern-ment are prepared to accept in principle this offer of his good offices inthe search for an acceptable solution of the differences which exist between the Governments of Greece, Turkey, and the United Kingdomregarding Cyprus.2. In order that progress may be made simultaneously with theintroduction of internal self-government on the lines of Lord Radcliffe'srecommendations, Her Majesty's Government propose to summon at anearly date a conference in London of leaders of the various Cypriotcommunities.1- 1543, Meanwhile Her Majesty'?, Government have noted the declarationof the leader of EOKA that his organisation would suspend its operationsas soon as Archbishop Makarios was released. They are informing the archbishop of this statement. They assume that in this new situationhe will be willing publicly to recommend the cessation of terroristactivity. In that event Her Majesty's Government will be ready to bring to an end his detention in the Seychelles, and they would raise noobjection to his taking his place as a member of the conference to beheld in London. They must, however, reserve to themselves thedecision on the appropriate time when it will be possible to allow himto return to Cyprus.4. So far as concerns the international aspects of the cyprus problem, Her Majesty's Government consider that these should be explored through the medium of the North Atlantic Council.
